Seated behind an old four-pedal piano, a derby
tilted above his deep-socketed eyes, Max Morath
looks like an old Tin Pan Alley song plugger.
That is how millions are seeing Max Morath in
“The Ragtime Era,” a series of which he is the
writer and narrator. The twelve-week series was
produced by KRMA-TV, the ETV station in
Denver, and began being shown on the NET net¬
work in the fall of 1960. But Morath is neither
old nor a song plugger. He is thirty-three and a
graduate of Colorado College, with a major in
English. He did graduate work at Stanford Uni¬
versity. Music, particularly the music reflecting
the colorful days of the mining boom in the Colo¬
rado hills, is his stock in trade as a composer and
recording artist.
On the surface, “The Ragtime Era” is a musical
series—Morath at the piano, by himself most of
the time, occasionally with a barbershop quartet,
a ballroom dance team, or a Dixieland band. Be¬
neath the surface, the series presents a cultural
history of the United States from 1890 to 1920
through a study of popular music. Between songs,
Morath describes what he terms “the personality
and morals of America in a time that, in retro¬
spect, was gentle and naive.” The series was con¬
ceived through the familiarity of one of KRMA’s
producers with Cripple Creek, an old gold-mining
camp that has been restored. Morath is musical
director of the summer season of musical melo¬
dramas at Cripple Creek’s Old Imperial Hotel.
The series also traces the beginning of unique
American contributions to music: ragtime, jazz,
and musical comedy. It conveys basic knowledge
of syncopation, improvisation, time signatures
and rhythm, harmony, and the structure of pop¬
ular musical forms. Collaborating with Morath
in research for “The Ragtime Era” is Dr. Albert
Seay, a musical scholar who teaches at Colorado
College. The series draws material from Morath’s
years of research, his extensive library of refer¬
ence works and sheet music, and a collection of
10,000 song slides owned by a Topeka, Kansas,
man.
